moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4
comment:
This rarely adopted variation
transfers to the second player the attack, which is, however, a short-lived
one if properly defended.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4
comment:
This sacrifice of the knight is a
novel introduction. 5...d4 is generally preferred at this point, and is
usually continued thus: 5...d4 6.exf6 dxc3 7.b3 Qxf6 8.Nf3 Bg4 9.Be2 Nc6 etc.,
and most practitioners pronounce the game even.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4
comment:
The saving clause which redeems White's game,
and leaves the opponent no option but to lose a move with the only piece he
has got in play besides his queen.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5
comment:
Black would have lost a piece
if he had taken the knight with the pawn checking, for White would have simply
retaken with the pawn, and Black would have been compelled to sacrifice the
pinned bishop for the adverse f-pawn, and then White's king would have easily
reached a safe goal after a few checks from the opponent.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3
comment:
A number of
ingenious traps were laid for White by Black's last move. Had he now moved 11.
Kd2, the reply would have been 11...Qg4; and if White attacked the queen by 12.
h3, Black would have checked with the queen at f4, followed by 13...Qg3+, if
13.Ke1 or, in the other alternative, if 13.Kd1, he would have won, by 13...
exf3, followed by 14...fxg2+, in answer to 14.Bxf4 etc. Again, if White now
moved 11.Kd1 at once, Black might have sacrificed the queen by 11...exf3; for,
if 12.Qxh4 in reply, he could also proceed to leave the bishop en prise by 12..
.fxg2+, winning the rook and making a new queen.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+
comment:
The only move to prevent an immediate draw, which Black would have obtained by
checking backwards and forwards with the queen at e1 and h4, if White had
captured the bishop at once with the pawn. White wished to avoid thatcontingenc
y, relying upon his king getting into the middle of the board, ready to
support the pawns of both wings, if he succeeded in exchanging queens, which
would be more favorable to him in the endgame.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+
comment:
Much superior to exchanging queens at once, whereupon White would have
retaken with the king. White's king is now driven more to the rear and the
exchange can be afforded more conveniently on the next move. If White in reply
move 15.f4, Black would obtain a good game by 15...Nc6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2
1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6
comment:
Black chose this mode of development for the knight
with the object of getting rid of the hostile bishop as early as possible. 16..
.Nd7 would have led to various complications of a character which must have
made Black's game exceedingly difficult, for White would have replied 17.Rg1
attacking the g-pawn, which could not be defended by 17...g6 or 17...0-0, on
account of the rejoinder 18.e6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4
comment:
[?:??-1:00]  Black could not
afford to allow the bishop to be planted at d6, and the sacrifice of the pawn
was quite judicious under the circumstances that White's material advantage
consisted afterwards in a doubled pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6
comment:
Taking the c-pawn would have led to an exchange disadvantageous to Black, e.g.
: 20...Qxc3 21.Qxc3 Rxc3 22.Rxb7 Rxc2+ 23.Ke3, and wins the a-pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6
comment:
The counter attack looked promising at first
sight; but 23...Rc5, with the object of castling, was in reality safer play.
White's best reply was then to challenge the exchange of queens by 24.Qa4, and
he would have still retained the best of the game, but his chances of winning
must have been considerably diminished in that case.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5
comment:
"A desperate
sortie, which involves the exposure of the K to a strong attack by White's
forcible reply. Q to B 8 offered better chances of recovering ground, though
White would even then have kept the attack in hand by Q to R 4, ch. followed
either by Q takes R P, or by R to Kt 4, according to Black's reply."

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5 25. e6 fxe6
comment:
Black had nothing better, for White threatened an extremely harassing
check at a4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5 25. e6 fxe6 26. Qa4+ Ke7
comment:
Again the only move. Had he interposed the rook,
White would have won as follows, supposing-26...Rd7 27.Rd4 Qg7 28.Rxb6 axb6 29.
Qa8+ Ke7 30.Rxd7+ Kf6 (best; for if 30...Kxd7, White wins the queen by 31.Qa7+)
31.hxg5+, and wins; for if 31...Kf5, White would reply 32.Qe4+.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5 25. e6 fxe6 26. Qa4+ Ke7 27. Qxa7+ Rd7 28. Qxb6 Rc8

1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5 25. e6 fxe6 26. Qa4+ Ke7 27. Qxa7+ Rd7 28. Qxb6 Rc8 29. Qe3 Kf7 30. Rb5 Rcd8 31. Rxg5 Rd2+ 32. Kg3 R2d6 33. Rf4+
comment:
[2:00-?:??]; The following note leads me to suspect that Black's
32nd move is actually 32...Rd1 (R-Q8 vs R-Q3 in descriptive). If this is the
case then the note dealing with the exchange of two rooks for queen begins to
make sense (R to B 4, ch. being Rf5+ so the pawn can capture on f5!-[Pope];
"Here White missed the shortest way of winning the game right off. He ought to
have doubled the rooks by moving the same rook to K Kt 4, threatening Q to B 4,
ch. followed by R to Kt 7, ch. He might have also won here two rooks for the Q
by R to B 4, ch. Black had then nothing better than to capture the R with the
P, for if he attempted to support the Q by K to Kt 3, R to B 6, ch. followed.
But the latter mode of play left, however, the chances of long protracted and
perhaps complicated fight open, and the line of play in the text had therefore
the preference of greater simplicity, though it was not as prompt and decisive
as our first suggestion."

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5 25. e6 fxe6 26. Qa4+ Ke7 27. Qxa7+ Rd7 28. Qxb6 Rc8 29. Qe3 Kf7 30. Rb5 Rcd8 31. Rxg5 Rd2+ 32. Kg3 R2d6 33. Rf4+ Ke7 34. Qe5
comment: There was only one answer to this, and that was the one actually made.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 4. d3 Bb4 5. fxe5 Nxe4 6. dxe4 Qh4+ 7. Ke2 Bxc3 8. bxc3 Bg4+ 9. Nf3 dxe4 10. Qd4 Bh5 11. Ke3 Bxf3 12. Bb5+ c6 13. gxf3 cxb5 14. Qxe4 Qh6+ 15. Kf2 Qc6 16. Qd4 Na6 17. Ba3 b4 18. Bxb4 Nxb4 19. Qxb4 Rc8 20. Rab1 b6 21. Rb3 Rd8 22. Re1 Rd5 23. Re4 Qh6 24. h4 g5 25. e6 fxe6 26. Qa4+ Ke7 27. Qxa7+ Rd7 28. Qxb6 Rc8 29. Qe3 Kf7 30. Rb5 Rcd8 31. Rxg5 Rd2+ 32. Kg3 R2d6 33. Rf4+ Ke7 34. Qe5 Rd5 35. Rg7+ Ke8 36. Qf6
comment:
36.Qc7 would have been of no use, for Black would
have replied with 36...R8d7. The move in text forces the exchange, and leaves
Black no game to fight with.
